article.headline: Panthers have won five straight in series
article.linkText: Pittsburgh rains on W. Virginia's anniversary
article.story: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. (AP) -- Jerry West didn't attend a 100th anniversary celebration of West Virginia basketball. The Mountaineers could have used a player with his scoring touch against Pittsburgh (No. 4 ESPN/USA Today, No. 5 AP). Instead, Pittsburgh continued its recent dominance against its neighbor 70 miles to the south, beating West Virginia 67-58 Saturday night before a rare sellout crowd in Morgantown. "We overcame a lot of obstacles with the crowd and the 100th anniversary thing," Pittsburgh coach Jamie Dixon said. "I think our guys responded in a tremendous way." Pittsburgh's Julius Page and Chevon Troutman each scored 15 points. Carl Krauser added 13 and Chris Taft scored 10. The Panthers (24-2, 10-2 Big East) have won five straight in the series, earning only its sixth win in 26 games at the Coliseum. "You never want to play from behind because it can get real loud in here," Krauser said. West Virginia (14-9, 6-6) had trouble with its inside offense despite the presence of 6-foot-11 D'or Fischer and 6-10 Kevin Pittsnogle. Tyrone Sally led the Mountaineers with 17 points, while Joe Herber had 14 rebounds. West Virginia played its first basketball game 100 years ago Friday, when it beat Pitt's predecessor, Western University of Pennsylvania. As part of Saturday's celebration, the Mountaineers wore uniforms resembling those worn by its 1959 NCAA runner-up team led by West. They couldn't capitalize on the festive atmosphere and the momentum from six wins in eight games. The Mountaineers shot just 35 percent from the field and slowly tired against the nation's sixth-best scoring defense. "They are very good at making people miss shots," West Virginia coach John Beilein said. "We gave it everything we had. We're just not good enough. We weren't able to score inside at all." Pittsburgh shot 62.5 percent from the field in the first half and had to repel a late rally by West Virginia. The Panthers closed the half with a 12-2 run for a 38-30 lead. Page hit a 3-pointer for Pittsburgh's largest lead, 49-35, with 13:15 left in the game, and soon Panthers fans started chanting "Defense!" over the hushed sellout crowd. West Virginia fought back with four long baskets over the next 3 minutes. The Mountaineers eventually pulled within 59-56 on a running jumper by Tyler Relph with 2:47 left. But Herber missed the front end of a bonus free throw with 1:17 to go and West Virginia got no closer. "We got a little dependent on the 3 at the end," Herber said. "There wasn't a lot going on inside because they were stronger underneath." Pittsburgh remained in first place in the conference, one game ahead of No. 8 Connecticut and Providence, which also won Saturday. West Virginia has lost nine straight games to ranked opponents. The Mountaineers haven't beaten a Top 25 team in Morgantown in three years. "Pitt's just better than us right now," Beilein said. "If you can't make your shots, it's tough."<
